data.name: Dressing Case | Europe, 18th Century | NPM Enameled Ware 000902
data.description: This compact dressing case assembles a miniature set of personal grooming tools designed for travel and daily refinement. Such cases typically contain a small mirror, glass bottles for perfumes or aromatic powders, and implements such as knives, scissors, and tweezers. The exterior is often lavishly decorated—its panels inlaid with painted enamel plaques, mother-of-pearl, agate, or multicolored gemstones—capturing the opulent aesthetic of eighteenth-century European craftsmanship. Portable yet sumptuous, these cases reflect a world in which elegance accompanied every gesture, even those performed in private.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A small rectangular European dressing case decorated with painted enamel panels featuring flowers and foliage. The box is framed with gilt metal mounts and rests on four tiny feet. A curved gilt handle rises elegantly from the lid, giving the piece a refined and decorative appearance.
